results.title: Where NASA Put a Parking Lot, Dinosaurs and Mammals Once Crossed Paths
results.abstract: An 8.5-foot-long slab found in Maryland preserved tracks left by prehistoric creatures. The site was almost obliterated before the rock was unearthed.

multimedia.caption: A nearly 9-foot slab of rock found in a parking lot on the grounds of NASA’s Goddard Spaceflight Center holds the fossilized tracks of several dinosaurs and even a few early mammals.
A nearly 9-foot slab of rock found in a parking lot on the grounds of NASA’s Goddard Spaceflight Center holds the fossilized tracks of several dinosaurs and even a few early mammals.

results.title: The Famine Ended 70 Years Ago, but Dutch Genes Still Bear Scars
results.abstract: Babies born during the Dutch Hunger Winter became adults with higher rates of health problems. Now researchers may have found the genetic switches that made it happen.

multimedia.caption: A victim of starvation during the Dutch famine of 1944-45. Women pregnant during the period gave birth to babies who were affected by health problems throughout their lives.
A victim of starvation during the Dutch famine of 1944-45. Women pregnant during the period gave birth to babies who were affected by health problems throughout their lives.
A victim of starvation during the Dutch famine of 1944-45. Women pregnant during the period gave birth to babies who were affected by health problems throughout their lives.

results.title: How to Get a Killer Whale to Say ‘Hello’
results.abstract: Researchers trained an orca to mimic human sounds like, “hello,” “Amy” and “bye-bye,” which could contribute to understanding of the behavior and culture of killer whales in the wild.
org_facet: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

results.title: The Super Blue Blood Moon: Pictures From an Astronomical Hat Trick
results.abstract: Around the world, people woke up early or stayed up late to take in the cosmic coincidence of a blue moon, a supermoon and a lunar eclipse.
geo_facet: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

results.title: There’s No Place Like Home, Especially if It’s Made of Hemp
results.abstract: Widely used in other countries, a variety of the cannabis plant is providing contractors with more efficient construction materials for houses and other structures.

multimedia.caption: Russians sorting raw hemp fibers in the Kursk region in the 1960s. Hemp has been used as building material for millennia in Europe and elsewhere, but it’s only just starting to get wider recognition as a green construction option.

Russians sorting raw hemp fibers in the Kursk region in the 1960s. Hemp has been used as building material for millennia in Europe and elsewhere, but it’s only just starting to get wider recognition as a green construction option.

results.title: Elephants Are Very Scared of Bees. That Could Save Their Lives.
results.abstract: Researchers have compared the reactions of elephants in Africa and Asia to bee swarms, in efforts at protecting the endangered animals from angered farmers or poachers.

multimedia.caption: A bee’s sting won’t hurt an elephant’s tough hide, but bees can swarm and wound more sensitive places like the trunk, eyes and mouth.

results.title: A Suitcase-Size Satellite’s Big Image of Frozen Earth Below
results.abstract: A new image of Alaska from the recently launched Iceye satellite shows how much you can accomplish with a tiny satellite.

results.title: We’re Getting More Sleep. A Whole 18 Minutes. It’s Not Enough.
results.abstract: Starting in 2003, Americans added 1.4 minutes of sleep each year, for a gain of 18 minutes per weeknight through 2016, government data shows.

multimedia.caption: Studies suggest a good night’s sleep can help with everything from better concentration to managing your weight.
Studies suggest a good night’s sleep can help with everything from better concentration to managing your weight.

results.title: How a Church Deacon Found the Biggest Prime Number Yet (It Wasn’t as Hard as You Think)
results.abstract: The Memphis area man used the church computer to discover a Mersenne prime with over 23 million digits. He had been looking for 14 years.

multimedia.caption: Jon Pace is the discoverer of the largest known prime number, 23.2 million digits long.
Jon Pace is the discoverer of the largest known prime number, 23.2 million digits long.

results.title: The Next Big Volcano Could Briefly Cool Earth. NASA Wants to Be Ready.
results.abstract: By studying the natural effects of a large volcanic eruption, scientists could learn about how we might deliberately cool the planet in the future.

results.title: The Smiling Axolotl Hides a Secret: A Giant Genome
results.abstract: The Mexican salamander has largest genome ever sequenced, which may account for its unique regenerative abilities.

multimedia.caption: The axolotl is an salamander whose genome has 32 billion base pairs, ten times the number in the human genome and the largest ever sequenced.
The axolotl is an salamander whose genome has 32 billion base pairs, ten times the number in the human genome and the largest ever sequenced.

results.title: E.P.A. Blocks Obama-Era Clean Water Rule
results.abstract: President Trump has called the Waters of the United States rule, set to enter force in the coming weeks, “one of the worst examples of federal regulation.”

results.title: Dr. Brenda Fitzgerald, C.D.C. Director, Resigns Over Tobacco and Other Investments
results.abstract: Dr. Fitzgerald abruptly left the agency in the middle of a flu epidemic, following disclosures that she had recent investments in tobacco and health stocks.

results.title: Scott Pruitt, the E.P.A. Chief, Assailed Trump in a 2016 Interview
results.abstract: Speaking on a radio show in 2016, Mr. Pruitt said that Donald Trump, if elected, would act in a way that is “truly unconstitutional.”

multimedia.caption: Scott Pruitt in January. “I believe that Donald Trump in the White House would be more abusive to the Constitution than Barack Obama,” he said in 2016.
Scott Pruitt in January. “I believe that Donald Trump in the White House would be more abusive to the Constitution than Barack Obama,” he said in 2016.

results.title: Volkswagen Suspends Top Lobbyist Amid Inquiry Into Diesel Tests on Monkeys
results.abstract: Thomas Steg, a former top aide to Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, exemplified what critics say are the cozy ties between her government and the country’s carmakers.
org_facet: European Research Group on Environment and Health in the Transport Sector

multimedia.caption: Thomas Steg, Volkswagen’s chief lobbyist, was suspended on Tuesday amid scrutiny of German carmakers’ financing of diesel-emissions experiments on monkeys.
Thomas Steg, Volkswagen’s chief lobbyist, was suspended on Tuesday amid scrutiny of German carmakers’ financing of diesel-emissions experiments on monkeys.

results.title: Do ‘Fast and Furious’ Movies Cause a Rise in Speeding?
results.abstract: Evidence suggests you may want to be more cautious near theaters in April 2020, when “Fast and Furious 9” is expected to arrive.
results.byline: By ANUPAM B. JENA, AAKASH JAIN and TANNER R. HICKS

multimedia.caption: A traffic stop in Sacramento. Research suggests that watching movies about fast driving may encourage more fast driving.
A traffic stop in Sacramento. Research suggests that watching movies about fast driving may encourage more fast driving.

results.title: The Lunar Eclipse and Super Blue Moon Are Here. Watch It Before Work.
results.abstract: On Wednesday, Earth will cast its shadow over the second full moon of January, making it turn red in a lunar eclipse. Here’s when and where you can see it.
geo_facet: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

multimedia.caption: A supermoon during a lunar eclipse observed in Washington, D.C., in September 2015. On Wednesday morning, a rare “super blue blood moon” will be visible to people in the United States, with viewers on the West Coast with the best seats.

results.title: New Jersey Embraces an Idea It Once Rejected: Make Utilities Pay to Emit Carbon
results.abstract: Democratic governors nationwide are taking steps to tax or price emissions within their own borders, even as Trump dismantles federal climate policy.

multimedia.caption: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey during his inauguration in Trenton on Jan. 16. He has ordered the state to rejoin a regional carbon-trading program.

results.title: Scientists Discover a Bone-Deep Risk for Heart Disease
results.abstract: Few doctors, and even fewer patients, have heard of CHIP. But it is emerging as a major cause of heart attacks and stroke, as deadly as high blood pressure or cholesterol.

multimedia.caption: A colored scanning electron micrograph of a bone marrow stem cell. Scientists have learned that an accumulation of mutated stem cells in bone marrow dramatically increases a person’s risk of dying from a heart attack or stroke.

A colored scanning electron micrograph of a bone marrow stem cell. Scientists have learned that an accumulation of mutated stem cells in bone marrow dramatically increases a person’s risk of dying from a heart attack or stroke.

results.title: German Carmakers Criticized for Emissions Research on Monkeys
results.abstract: Tests that exposed monkeys to diesel exhaust provoked public outrage and are likely to intensify criticism of pro-diesel lobbying by carmakers.
org_facet: European Research Group on Environment and Health in the Transport Sector

multimedia.caption: Volkswagen vehicles being checked for quality at a plant in Wolfsburg, Germany. A Volkswagen Beetle was used as part of a diesel emissions test that has drawn intense criticism for its use of monkeys.

results.title: Space Gets an Artificial Star. Astronomers Ask: Do We Need More?
results.abstract: The launch of a spinning geodesic sphere called the Humanity Star has set off concerns about the growing number of bright objects illuminating the dark sky.

multimedia.caption: Peter Beck with the “Humanity Star,” which is made of carbon fiber and reflective panels. It has been compared to a disco ball, or a Dungeons and Dragons die.

results.title: Seed Size Often Matters
results.abstract: Small seeds can develop more quickly and spread more widely than large-seeded plant species, although bigger seeds can thrive in richer, wetter soils.

results.title: Citing Deaths of Lab Monkeys, F.D.A. Ends an Addiction Study
results.abstract: The agency said on Friday it was evaluating other animal studies and would retire the remaining monkeys to a sanctuary.

multimedia.caption: Squirrel monkeys contemplating a box in a zoo in Budapest, Hungary. Nicotine experiments funded by the F.D.A. resulted in the deaths of four monkeys like these.

results.title: More Than 150 Women Described Sexual Abuse by Lawrence Nassar. Will Their Testimony Help Them Heal?
results.abstract: The psychological effects of disclosing a traumatic secret — of telling your story — depend on the audience, the nature of the trauma and other factors.

results.title: Yale’s Most Popular Class Ever: Happiness
results.abstract: With nearly 1,200 students signed up, a course that tells students how to lead more satisfying lives may be the largest in university history.

multimedia.caption: Jennifer Chen, left, and Sean Guo are among the almost 1,200 students taking Laurie Santos’s “Psychology and the Good Life,” at Yale. The class was recently moved to Woolsey Hall, the university’s concert venue, from Battell Chapel, which could only accommodate a crowd of 800.

results.abstract: All states except Hawaii report widespread flu, federal officials said Friday. Infection and hospitalization rates are likely to equal or surpass those in 2009.

results.title: A Science Denier at the Natural History Museum? Scientists Rebel
results.abstract: More than 200 scientists and other academics are asking the American Museum of Natural History to remove Rebekah Mercer, an influential donor to conservative causes, from its board.

results.title: Swatting at Mosquitoes May Help You Avoid Bites, Even if You Miss
results.abstract: When a feeding situation isn’t favorable, a mosquito can switch preferences, and it may learn to associate your scent with avoiding your incoming hand.

multimedia.caption: An Aedes aegypti mosquito feeding on a person’s hand. A new study suggests that mosquitoes might learn to avoid people who swat at them, by recognizing their smell.
An Aedes aegypti mosquito feeding on a person’s hand. A new study suggests that mosquitoes might learn to avoid people who swat at them, by recognizing their smell.

results.abstract: The committee expressed doubts about the company’s health claims that the device, called IQOS, would cause less tobacco-related disease.

results.title: Billions of Plastic Pieces Litter Coral in Asia and Australia
results.abstract: Big and small pieces of plastic make coral more prone to disease, the researchers found, but it is possible to control the impact of coastal pollution on reefs.
geo_facet: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

results.title: You Are Shaped by the Genes You Inherit. And Maybe by Those You Don’t.
results.abstract: An unusual study of educational attainment in children finds that gene variants linked to parental nurturing were highly influential even though children had not inherited them.

multimedia.caption: Animal researchers have amassed a wealth of evidence showing that animals are influenced not just by their own genes but by the genes of their parents.
Animal researchers have amassed a wealth of evidence showing that animals are influenced not just by their own genes but by the genes of their parents.

results.title: In Cave in Israel, Scientists Find Jawbone Fossil From Oldest Modern Human Out of Africa
results.abstract: The discovery could rewrite the migration story of our species, pushing back by about 50,000 years when Homo sapiens were thought to have first left Africa.

multimedia.caption: A fossilized human jawbone discovered in Israel. The find may suggest that Homo sapiens first migrated out of Africa at least 50,000 years earlier than previously thought.
A fossilized human jawbone discovered in Israel. The find may suggest that Homo sapiens first migrated out of Africa at least 50,000 years earlier than previously thought.

results.title: Doomsday Clock Is Set at 2 Minutes to Midnight, Closest Since 1950s
results.abstract: The “clock,” kept by the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, is a symbolic measurement of scientists’ concerns about disaster.
des_facet: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

multimedia.caption: From left, Sivan Kartha, a senior scientist at the Stockholm Environmental Institute; Lawrence M. Krauss, director of the Arizona State University Origins Project; Robert Rosner, a theoretical physicist at the University of Chicago; and Sharon A. Squassoni, research professor at George Washington University, at a news conference in Washington on Thursday to announce that the Doomsday Clock had been set to two minutes to midnight.

From left, Sivan Kartha, a senior scientist at the Stockholm Environmental Institute; Lawrence M. Krauss, director of the Arizona State University Origins Project; Robert Rosner, a theoretical physicist at the University of Chicago; and Sharon A. Squassoni, research professor at George Washington University, at a news conference in Washington on Thursday to announce that the Doomsday Clock had been set to two minutes to midnight.
